Comments_List: unsettling myths of climate change and climate/society. finding optimism for a climate changed future through considering societal adaptation and evolution.
It was an introduction to many anthropological concepts for me, but I enjoyed learning about a new perspective for analysis.

Too much to summarize. This course offered great exercise in synthesizing diverse topics, disciplines, and data sources under one broad theme (climate).  This is how one learns how to do groundbreaking and novel work of the sort that all PhD students hope to do someday. A highly engaging and valuable course.
I learned a ton about anthropology and climate change, it's hard to verbally wrap my arms around everything I gained from this course.

The lectures and readings were as-expected. I found the content mostly engaging and the increasing class discussions towards the end of the semester helped to clarify a number of concepts I was unclear on.
strengths are the assigned readings and lectures

The strengths are the lectures and the experiences of professor Dove. I think the commentaries and discussion leaders are a strong component to the course, but could be improved to encourage more input from students and lively discussions.

I think the lecturing could engage with students more often by drawing in student commentary throughout the class session. Professors often incite brief discussions during class, and I think confining most of the discussion until after the lecture makes the course moderately less engaging.

take the class if you are considering any sort of future career or research around climate change or just generally depressed about what you think is an impending apocalypse (its not...take the class!).
Take notes during the readings-- you'll want to use at least a few  of them in your final paper.
